content.text:
# List of battles 301–1300

This is a list of battles from 301 A.D. to 1300 A.D.
4th century

|301
| rowspan="5" |War of the Eight Princes
|Battle of Yangdi–Huangqiao
| rowspan="7" |
|April—June
|Sima Jiong, Sima Ying and Sima Yong defeats Sima Lun.
|-
|303
|Siege of Luoyang
|September 303—March 304
|Sima Yong and Sima Ying defeats Sima Ai.
|-
| rowspan="2" |304
|Battle of Dangyin
|9 September
|Sima Ying defeats Sima Yue and captures Emperor Hui of Jin.
|-
|Battle of Pingji
|September
|Wang Jun and Sima Teng defeats Sima Ying.
|-
|306
|Sack of Chang'an
|June
|Sima Yue defeats Sima Yong and returns Emperor Hui of Jin to Luoyang.
|-
| rowspan="2" |311 || rowspan="2" | Upheaval of the Five Barbarians || Battle of Ningping|| May || Han-Zhao General Shi Le ambushes and annihilated the Jin army, Wang Yan executed.
|-
|Fall of Luoyang ||13—14 July || Han-Zhao capture the Jin Dynasty's capital and capture Emperor Huai of Jin.
|-
|  rowspan="5"|312 || rowspan="7" | Civil wars of the Tetrarchy || Siege of Segusio || rowspan="5" |  || Spring || The series of wars between Constantine and Maxentius starts.
|-
|Battle of Turin|| ||Constantine defeats forces loyal to Maxentius.
|-
|Battle of Brescia || Summer ||Maxentius sends Ruricus to lead an attack against Constantine, only to fail.
|-
|Battle of Verona || ||Constantine defeats Maxentius once more in an attack, Ruricus dying whilst leading it.
|-
|Battle of the Milvian Bridge|| 28 Oct || Constantine takes control of Italy, executing Maxentius and his family after.
|-
| 313 ||Battle of Tzirallum ||  || 30 April || In the eastern part of the Empire, the forces of Licinius defeat Maximinus Daia.
|-
| 314 || Battle of Cibalae ||  || || Constantine defeats Licinius.
|-
| rowspan="2" |316 || Upheaval of the Five Barbarians || Fall of Chang'an||  || || Han forces receives the surrender of Emperor Min of Jin; end of the Western Jin.
|-
| rowspan="4" | Civil wars of the Tetrarchy || Battle of Mardia ||  || Late 316 or early 317 || Constantine again defeats Licinius, who cedes Illyricum to Constantine.
|-
| rowspan="3" | 324 || Battle of Adrianople || rowspan="3" |  || 3 July || Constantine defeats Licinius, who flees to Byzantium.
|-
|Battle of the Hellespont || July || Flavius Julius Crispus, son of Constantine defeats the naval forces of Licinius.
|-
|Battle of Chrysopolis || 18 Sep || Constantine decisively defeats Licinius, establishing his sole control over the Empire.
|-
|328 || Sixteen Kingdoms ||Battle of Luoyang || || Aug/Sep 328—21 Jan 329 ||Later Zhao defeats the Former Zhao and captures their emperor, Liu Yao.
|-
| c. 330 || || Sack of Meroë ||  || || Kingdom of Axum under King Ezana sack the capital of the Kingdom of Kush, leading to Kush's collapse.
|-
|336 || Sixteen Kingdoms || Battle of Pingguo || || Feb ||Murong Huang defeats and captures his brother, Murong Ren.
|-
| 337 || Perso-Roman wars of 337-361 || Siege of Nisibis ||  || || Persians unsuccessfully siege Roman city.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 338 || Sixteen Kingdoms || Battle of Jicheng || || 12–16 June || Former Yan repels a Later Zhao invasion.
|-
| rowspan="4" | Perso-Roman wars of 337–361 || Siege of Nisibis ||  || 15 June—14 or 24 Aug || Shapur II besieges Nisibis for 60 days before returning to Persia.
|-
| 344 || Battle of Singara ||  || || Emperor Constantius II fights an indecisive battle against the Persian King Shapur II.
|-
| 346 || Siege of Nisibis|| rowspan="2" | || 346—347 || Persian King Shapur II again sieges the city and is repelled.
|-
| 350 ||Siege of Nisibis || || King Shapur II sieges Nisibis for the third time, flooding the city but ultimately being unsuccessful and retreats.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 351 || Roman civil war of 350–353 || Battle of Mursa Major ||  || 28 Sep || Emperor Constantius II defeats the usurper Magnentius.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Sixteen Kingdoms || Battle of Xiangguo || rowspan="2" | || Nov/Dec 350—April/May 351 || Later Zhao and Former Yan defeats Ran Wei. However, the last ruler of Later Zhao, Shi Zhi, is soon assassinated.
|-
|352 ||Battle of Liantai || 17 May ||Former Yan defeats Ran Wei and captures Ran Min.
|-
| 353 || Roman civil war of 350–353 || Battle of Mons Seleucus || rowspan="6" |  || Aug || Final defeat of Magnentius by Constantius II.
|-
| rowspan="4" | 356 || rowspan="5" | Roman–Alamanni conflict and Roman–Germanic Wars || Siege of Autun || || The city of Autun, Burgundy, is besieged by Alamanni forces. Julian the Apostate of Rome relieves the city, ending the siege.
|-
|Battle of Durocortorum || || Caesar Julian is defeated by the Alemanni.
|-
|Battle of Brumath|| || Roman troops under Julian destroy a Germanic war band in open battle.
|-
|Siege of Senonae||  || Germanic troops unsuccessfully besiege the city of Senonae, where Julian is staying for the winter.
|-
|357 ||Battle of Strasbourg || || Julian expels the Alamanni from the Rhineland.
|-
|359 || rowspan="2" | Perso-Roman wars of 337–361 || Battle of Amida ||  || || Sasanians capture Amida from the Romans.
|-
|360 ||Siege of Singara|| rowspan="3" |  || ||Sasanians take Singara.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 363 || rowspan="2" | Julian's Persian expedition || Battle of Ctesiphon || 29 May || Emperor Julian defeats Shapur II outside the walls of the Persian capital, but is unable to take the city, leading to an ultimate disaster on the retreat back to Roman territory.
|-
|Battle of Samarra|| June || Julian fights the Sasanians and is subsequently killed in battle. Though indecisive, the battle leads to massive losses for the Roman Empire through a forced peace treaty.
|-
|366 || Procopius' Rebellion || Battle of Thyatira ||  || || The army of the Roman Emperor Valens defeats the usurper Procopius.
|-
|367 || Roman–Alamanni conflict and Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of Solicinium ||  || || Romans under Emperor Valentinian I defeat yet another Alemanni incursion.
|-
|369 || Huan Wen's Northern Expeditions ||Battle of Fangtou || rowspan="2" |  || March/April—9 Nov || Former Yan and Former Qin defeats Eastern Jin forces led by Huan Wen.
|-
|370 || Conquest of Former Yan by Former Qin || Battle of Luchuan || Nov || Former Qin forces led by Wang Meng defeat Former Yan.
|-
| 373 || || Battle of the Tanais River ||  || || The Huns defeat the Alans near the Don, beginning the great period of the Germanic migrations.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 377 || rowspan="3"  | Gothic War and Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of the Willows || rowspan="2" |  || || Roman troops fight an inconclusive battle against the Goths.
|-
|Battle of Dibaltum || ||Goths, Alans and Huns defeat Romans.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 378 ||Battle of Adrianople ||  || 9 Aug || The Thervings under Fritigern defeat and kill the Eastern Roman Emperor Valens.
|-
| Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of Argentovaria ||  || || The Western Emperor Gratianus is victorious over the Alamanni, yet again.
|-
| 380 || Gothic War and Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of Thessalonica ||  || || The Goths under Fritigern fight and defeat a Roman army under Emperor Theodosius I.
|-
| 383 || Sixteen Kingdoms || Battle of Feishui ||  || 30 Nov || Fu Jiān is defeated by the Jin commander Xie An. The kingdom of the Former Qin collapses shortly thereafter.
|-
| 388 || rowspan="2" | Roman civil war || Battle of the Save ||  || || Emperor Theodosius I defeats the usurper Magnus Maximus. Also known as the Battle of Poetovio.
|-
| 394 ||Battle of the Frigidus ||  || 5-6 Sep || The Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius I defeats and kills the last Pagan-tolerant usurper Eugenius and his Frankish general Arbogast.
|-
| 395 || rowspan="2" | Sixteen Kingdoms || Battle of Canhe Slope|| rowspan="2" |  || 8 Dec || Part of the Later Yan campaign into Northern Wei territory; crushing defeat for the Later Yan forces.
|-
|397 ||Battle of Baisi || 23–24 March ||Northern Wei defeats the Later Yan, driving them out of the Central Plains.
|}

|402 || rowspan="2" | Gothic War and Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of Pollentia || rowspan="4"|  || 6 April || Romans under Flavius Stilicho win a small victory against the Visigoths under Alaric.
|-
|403 ||Battle of Verona || June ||Stilicho defeats the Visigoths under Alaric, forcing them out of Italy.
|-
|405 || War of Radagaisus || Siege of Florence || ||Stilcho defends city from the Goths, but Florence is nearly destroyed.
|-
| rowspan="2" |406 || War of Radagaisus and Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of Faesulae || ||Stilicho defeats Visigoths and Vandals under Radagaisus.
|-
| Vandal–Frankish war || Battle of Mainz||  || || An army of Vandals, Suevi, and Alans defeats the Frankish federation.
|-
| rowspan="3" |409 || Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Ostia ||  || || Visigoths under Alaric I defeat Romans.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Liu Yu's Northern Expeditions || Battle of Linqu || rowspan="2" |  || || Eastern Jin decisively defeats Southern Yan.
|-
|Siege of Guanggu || ||Jin dynasty conquer Southern Yan
|-
|410 || rowspan="4" | Fall of the Roman Empire || Sack of Rome ||  || 24 Aug || The Visigoths under Alaric sack Rome.
|-
|413 ||Siege of Massilia ||  || || Visigoths under Ataulf are defeated by Romans under Bonifacius while trying to siege Roman city. They make peace with Rome soon after.
|-
|419 || Battle of the Nervasos Mountains || rowspan="2" |  || || Suebi under Hermeric allied with Romans in Hispania defeat coalition between the Vandals and Alans.
|-
|422 ||Battle of Tarraco || || The Vandals defeat the Western Roman Empire.
|-
|425 ||Gothic revolt of Theodoric I || Siege of Arles|||| || The Roman general Aëtius defeats the Visigoths under Theodoric I.
|-
|428 || rowspan="4" | Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Mérida ||  || || Vandals defeat Suebi.
|-
| 430 || Siege of Hippo Regius ||  || June 430—Aug 431 || Vandals under Genseric establish a foothold in Africa, strategically defeating Rome. Saint Augustine dies during the siege.
|-
| 431 || Battle of Helena ||  || || Romans defeat Franks.
|-
|432 ||Battle of Rimini ||  || || The Roman general Aëtius is defeated by his rival Count Boniface, who is killed.
|-
|436 || Gothic War || Battle of Narbonne ||  || 436—437 || Aëtius again defeats the Visigoths under Theodoric I.
|-
| rowspan="2" |439 || rowspan="4" | Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Carthage ||  || 19 Oct || Romans lose Carthage to the Vandals.
|-
|Battle of Toulouse ||  || || Visigoths led by Theodoric I defeat Romans under General Litorius, who is killed.
|-
|447 ||Battle of the Utus ||  || || Hunnic victory, led by Attila, over Roman forces in what is today Bulgaria.
|-
|445 || Battle of Vicus Helena ||  ||  c. 445—450 || Romans under Aëtius defeated the Franks under Chlodio.
|-
|450 || Legends of the Germanic heroic age || Battle of Finnsburg ||  || || Possibly mythical battle where Frisians allied with Jutes fight and are defeated by Danes in the Germanic heroic age. Frisian King Finn and Danish Prince Hnæf both supposedly died in combat.
|-
| rowspan="2" |451 || || Battle of Avarayr ||  || 26 May || Forces of Yazdegerd II annihilate the Christian Armenian rebels led by Saint Vartan.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Châlons ||  ||20 June || An alliance under Visigothic king Theodoric I and Romans under Aëtius repulse the attack of Attila the Hun and his allies. Theodoric is killed in the battle.
|-
|452 ||Sack of Aquileia ||  || 18 July || Aquileia is razed to the ground by the forces of Attila the Hun.
|-
|454 || Germanic-Hunnic Wars || Battle of Nedao || || ||A Germanic alliance under the leadership of the Ostrogoths and the Gepids breaks Hunnic power in Europe.
|-
| rowspan="2" |455 || Roman–Germanic Wars || Sack of Rome||  || 2–6 June || The Vandals sack Rome during their campaign against Emperor Petronius Maximus, looting the city for 14 days.
|-
| Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain || Battle of Aylesford||  || ||Britons and Anglo-Saxons battle in Kent, victory is unclear.
|-
| rowspan="2" |456 || rowspan="4" | Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Corsica || || || Romans repel Vandal attempt to annex Corsica.
|-
|Battle of Órbigo || || || Theodoric II, king of the Visigoths defeats the Suevi, sacks their capital, and conquers Spain.
|-
| rowspan="2" |457 || Battle of Garigliano || rowspan="2" |  || || Romans under Majorian defeat the Vandals.
|-
|Battle of Campi Cannini || ||Romans under Majorian defeats the Alemanni.
|-
| rowspan="2" |458 || Gothic War and Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Arelate || rowspan="2" |  || Late 458 || The Roman Emperor Majorian, with the support of Aegidius and Nepotianus, defeats the Visigoths at Arlate.
|-
| rowspan="3" | Fall of the Roman Empire  || Battle of Toulouse || ||The Roman Emperor Majorian defeats the Visigoths.
|-
|461 ||Battle of Cartagena ||  || || A Vandal fleet surprises and destroys the Roman fleet.
|-
|461 ||Battle of Bergamo ||  || || Romans under General Ricimer defeat Roman followers of emperor Majorian.
|-
|463 || Roman–Germanic Wars || Battle of Orleans ||  || || Kingdom of Soissons and Alans led by Aegidius defeat Visigoths under Theodoric II.
|-
|465 || Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain || Battle of Wippedesfleot ||  || ||The Saxons under Hengest battle the Britons, victory is undecided.
|-
| rowspan="2" |468 || Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Bolia ||  || || Ostrogoths defeat a coalition of Gepids, Heruli, Rugii, Sarmatians, Sciri, Suebi and the Roman Empire.
|-
| Vandal War and Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Cape Bon ||  |||| Vandals decisively defeat large joint effort by Western Roman Empire and Eastern Roman Empire to retake Carthage.
|-
|469 || rowspan="4" | Fall of the Roman Empire || Battle of Déols || rowspan="2" |  || || Visigoths defeat Bretons.
|-
|471 ||Battle of Arles || || Visigoths defeat the Western Roman Empire.
|-
|472 ||Siege of Rome || rowspan="2" |  || March—July ||Ricimer, having fallen out with his choice for Roman Emperor, allies with the Burgundians and Germans under Odoacer, defeats and kills the Roman Emperor Anthemius.
|-
|476 ||Battle of Ravenna || 2-4 Sep || The Germanic foederati led by Odoacer decisively defeat the Western Roman Empire and depose Emperor Romulus Augustulus. Western Roman Empire dissolved.
|-
|484 || Hephthalite–Sasanian War of 484 || Battle of Herat ||  || ||| Hephthalite Empire decisively defeats the Sasanian Empire and kills King Peroz I.
|-
|485 || Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain || Battle of Mercredesburne ||  || || Saxons under Aelle defeat British defenders.
|-
|486 || Campaigns of Clovis I || Battle of Soissons ||  || || Clovis I defeats Syagrius and gains the Domain of Soissons.
|-
| rowspan="3" |489 || Conquest of Italy by Theodoric the Great || Battle of Isonzo ||  ||28 Aug || Odoacer fights the Ostrogoths under Theodoric the Great, ending in the Italian troops' defeat.
|-
|  || Battle of Sirmium ||  || Aug || King Theodoric the Great of the Ostrogoths defeats king Thraustila of the Gepids.
|-
|rowspan="2" | Conquest of Italy by Theodoric the Great || Battle of Verona||rowspan="2" |  || 30 Sep || Odoacer fights the Ostrogoths near Verona, and is defeated a second time.
|-
|490||Siege of Ravenna || Late 490—5 March 493 || Odoacer holds out against Theodoric the Great until the Ostrogothic king is able to enforce a naval blockade on the city. Several days after a truce is negotiated to end the siege, Theodoric kills Odoacer with his own hands.
|-
|492 || Isaurian War || Battle of Cotyaeum ||  || ||  Byzantine army under John the Scythian defeats Isaurians under Longinus of Cardala.
|-
|496 || Campaigns of Clovis I || Battle of Tolbiac  ||  || || Franks under Clovis I defeat the Alamanni, killing their king.
|-
|497 || rowspan="2" | First Hunnic War || Sack of Kausambi || rowspan="2" |  || || Alchon Huns sack the central Indian city of Kosambi.
|-
|498 ||First Battle of Eran || ||Alchon Huns decisively defeat the Gupta Empire and annex Malwa.
|}

|-
|Siege of Martyropolis || || Sasanians take Byzantine city.
|-
| Siege of Amida || Oct 502—Jan 503 || Byzantine city holds out for three months without reinforcements against Persian siege led by Kavadh I before they eventually take the city until the Byzantines ransom it back in a treaty two years later.
|-

|| Battle of zanaeb || rowspan="2" |   || ||Taghlib victory in zanaeb valley in Najd.
|-
| Battle darya  ||  ||Taghlib victory in Darya near Al-Qassim Province.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 506 || Campaigns of Clovis I || Battle of Strasbourg|||| || The Franks under Clovis I defeats the Alemanni.
|-
| || Battle of Zhongli ||  || 506-507 ||Northern Wei invaded Liang Dynasty, but the attack failed.
|-
|507 || Franco–Gothic War || Battle of Vouillé|||| || The Franks under Clovis I defeat the Visigoths under Alaric II decisively, gaining Gallia Aquitania. Clovis kills Alaric in single combat.
|-
|510 || First Hunnic War || Second Battle of Eran |||| || Alchon Huns defeat the Guptas and temporarily conquer the province of Malwa.
|-
|512 || War of the Visigothic Succession || Battle of Barcelona |||| ||
The Ostrogothic Kingdom under Ibbas defeats Visigothic rebels under Gesalec.
|-
|518 || Anglo-Saxon conquest of Britain || Battle of Mons Badonicus ||  || || Or Battle of Mynydd Baddon. British forces defeat the Saxons decisively, ending their advance into British lands. Later connected to King Arthur.
|-
|520 || Second Hunnic War || Sack of Pataliputra |||| || Alchon Huns under Mihirakula sack and devastate the capital of the Gupta Empire, leading to the permanent decline of both the Gupta Empire and Pataliputra as a city.
|-
|522 || Basus War || Battle of the shaved heads |||| || Banu Bakr soldiers shave their heads so that they would know each others on the battlefield , Banu Bakr defeat Taghlib
|-
|524 || Invasion of Burgundy || Battle of Vézeronce |||| 25 June || Burgundians and Ostrogoths under Theodoric the Great defeat the Merovingian Franks.
|-
| rowspan="2" |525 || || Battle on the Rhine |||| || The army of king Theudebert I of Austrasia and a king in Frisia defeat an army of Danes.
|-
| Aksumite invasion of Himyar || siege of sanaa|||| || Kingdom of Aksum under Kaleb of Axum annexes the Himyarite Kingdom of Dhu Nuwas.
|-
| rowspan="2" |528 || Iberian War || Battle of Thannuris |||| Summer || Sasanians defeat Byzantines under Belisarius, but take heavy losses.
|-
| Second Hunnic War || Battle of Sondani || || ||Alliance of Indian rulers defeat the Alchon Huns, who retreat out of India.
|-
| rowspan="5" |530 || rowspan="2" | Iberian War || Battle of Dara|| rowspan="2" | || June || Byzantine commander Belisarius, in alliance with Heruli and the Huns, defeats Sasanian Persians in Turkey.
|-
|Battle of Satala ||Summer || Byzantines under Sittas and Dorotheus defeat attacking Persians under Mermeroes.
|-
|  || Banu Asad Revolt against Hujr of kinda|| rowspan="2" |||  || Banu Asad Revolt against Kingdom of Kinda and kill king Hujr .
|-
|  || Imru' al-Qais' attack on Asad tribe||||Imru' al-Qais with the help of Taghlib tribe exacts revenge on Banu Asad for killing his father "Hujr" killing many of them , but he fails to regain control of the throne of his father
|-
|| || Battle on the Ice of Lake Vänern |||| || Between Eadgils and his uncle King Onela of Sweden with the help of Beowulf. This event appears in several Norse sagas and in the Anglo-Saxon epic Beowulf.
|-
| rowspan="3" |531 || rowspan="2" | Iberian War ||  Battle of Callinicum|||| 19 April || A Sasanian army defeats a Byzantine force in Syria, but with heavy losses on both sides.
|-
|Siege of Martyropolis |||| Autumn || Sasanians withdraw from attack on Byzantine city, last battle of the Iberian War.
|-
| || Battle of the Unstrut River |||| || Frankish King Theuderic I defeats Thuringian King Hermanafrid and conquers Thuringia
|-
|532 || || Battle of Autun |||| || Frankish kings Childebert I and Chlothar I defeat the Burgundians and conquer their territory.
|-
| rowspan="2" |533 || rowspan="2" | Vandalic War || Battle of Ad Decimum || rowspan="4" | || 13 Sep || Belisarius defeats the Vandals under Gelimer near Carthage.
|-
|Battle of Tricamarum || 15 Dec || Belisarius again defeats the Vandals near Carthage, ending Vandal rule in North Africa.
|-
|534 || rowspan="2" | Byzantine–Moorish wars || Battle of Mammes || || rowspan="2" | Byzantine general Solomon defeats the Moorish rebels and secures control of Byzacena.
|-
|535 || Battle of Mount Bourgaon || Summer
|-
|536 || Gothic War || Siege of Naples |||| Oct—Nov || Byzantines under Belisarius take city from the Ostrogoths.
|-
| rowspan="3" |537 || Matter of Britain || Battle of Camlann |||| || King Arthur killed, perhaps mythical, by Mordred.
|-
| Byzantine–Moorish wars|| Battle of Scalas Veteres |||| Spring || Germanus defeats rebel African army.
|-
| || Battle of Shayuan || || || Western Wei dynasty defeats the Eastern Wei dynasty
|-
|538 || Gothic War || Siege of Rome |||| || Unsuccessful siege of Rome by the Ostrogoths, Byzantine defenders under Belisarius remain victorious.
|-
| rowspan="3" |540 || rowspan="2" |Byzantine–Moorish wars|| Battle of Babosis || rowspan="2" | || || rowspan="2" | Byzantine general Solomon defeats the Moorish rebels of the Aurès Mountains region and secures control of Numidia and Mauretania Sitifensis.
|-
| Battle of Zerboule ||
|-
| || Siege of Banavasi |||| || Chalukyas under Kirttivarman I defeat Kadamba dynasty and annex their capital of Banavasi.
|-
| rowspan="2" |541 || Lazic War || Siege of Petra |||| Feb—June || Sasasians under Khosrow I capture Byzantine fortress.
|-
| rowspan="3" | Gothic War || Siege of Verona || rowspan="3" | || Winter || Ostrogoths under Totila defend city against larger Byzantine army.
|-
| rowspan="2" |542 || Battle of Faventia || Spring || Ostrogoths under Totila defeat Byzantine army.
|-
|Battle of Mucellium || || Ostrogoths defeat Byzantine army.
|-
|543 || rowspan="2" |Lazic War || Battle of Anglon |||| || A Byzantine invasion of Sasanian Armenia is defeated by a small force under Nabedes.
|-
| rowspan="2" |544 || Siege of Edessa |||| March—April || Sasanians under Khosrow I abandon siege of Byzantine city of Edessa, which pays them 5 centenaria of gold.
|-
| rowspan="5" | Byzantine–Moorish wars ||Battle of Cillium || rowspan="5" |  || ||Byzantine General Solomon killed in battle by a coalition of Berber tribes.
|-
|545 || Battle of Thacia || Autumn || Stotzas mortally wounded by Byzantine general John.
|-
|546 || Battle of Sufetula || Late 546 or early 547 || Byzantine general John Troglita defeats the Moorish rebels under Antalas.
|-
|547 || Battle of Marta || Late summer || John Troglita is defeated by a coalition of Tripolitanian Moors.
|-
|548 || Battle of the Fields of Cato || Summer || John Troglita defeats the last Moorish coalition and suppresses the Moorish revolt.
|-
|550 || Lazic War || Siege of Petra |||| Summer 550—Spring 551 || Byzantines recapture city and dismantle its walls.
|-
|551 || rowspan="2" | Gothic War || Battle of Sena Gallica|| rowspan="2" | || Autumn || A Byzantine naval squadron defeats the Ostrogoth fleet decisively.
|-
| rowspan="2" |552 || Battle of Taginae|| July || Byzantines under Narses defeat Ostrogoths under Totila, who dies in battle.
|-
| || Battle of Asfeld || || || Longobards under King Audoin defeat the Gepids under Thurisind, who is killed.
|-
| rowspan="2" |553|| Gothic War || Battle of Mons Lactarius |||| Oct 552 or early 553 || Byzantines under Narses defeat the Ostrogoths under Teia, ending Ostrogoth resistance.
|-
| Lazic War || Battle of Telephis-Ollaria |||| || Sasanians defeat Byzantines.
|-
| rowspan="3" |554 || Gothic War || Battle of the Volturnus |||| Oct || Byzantines under Narses defeat the Franks and Alamanni decisively.
|-
| || Yawm Halima ("Day of Halima")|||| June || The Ghassanids under al-Harith ibn Jabalah defeat the Lakhmids under al-Mundhir III ibn al-Nu'man, who is killed.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Lazic War || Siege of Onoguris|| rowspan="2" | || 554 or 555 || Sasanians decisively defeat Byzantines and force them to retreat from the area and abandon Archaeopolis, which they subsequently raze.
|-
|555 || Siege of Phasis || July 555—June 556 || Byzantines defeat Sasanian siege of town.
|-
|556 || Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain ||Battle of Beran Byrig ||||||West Saxons under Cynric and his son Ceawlin defeat Britons.
|-
|559 || Byzantine-Kutrigurs war 558–559 || Battle of Melantias |||| March || Byzantines under Belisarius defeat the Kutrigurs  west of Constantinople.
|-
| rowspan="2" |560 || Hephthalite–Sasanian Wars || Battle of Gol-Zarriun |||| || Sasanians under King Khosrow I allied with the Göktürks decisively defeat the Hephthalite Empire, which dissolved into smaller kingdoms in the aftermath.
|-

|-

|-
||Dahis and al-Ghabra|| Tayy raid on Banu Abs |||| || Banu Abs repel the attack of Tayy tribe with the help of Antarah ibn Shaddad
